citations.narrative:
The wolf-dog hybrid, Blackie, is not up-to-date on her rabies vaccination. Her last rabies vaccination was in May 2019
and is due every three years (May 2022) as written in the facility's program of veterinary care for dogs. The animal had a
physical exam by a veterinarian a month prior to the vaccine due date, however, the facility forgot to vaccinate the dog the
following month. The wolf-dog hybrid appeared healthy during the inspection.
It's important for facilities to follow their program of veterinary care and vaccinate dogs for preventable contagious and
deadly diseases to ensure their health.
Each exhibitor with dogs must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that includes vaccinations for diseases
including rabies, parvovirus and distemper.
Correct by: March 16, 2023.

The fencing, in the rear of the zebra and cattle pens, has various areas of damage due to fallen trees. In the zebra
enclosure, a large tree has fallen onto the wooden fencing which has broken seven of the horizontal boards. The facility
has removed the broken boards but the tree remains and the fencing in that area is approximately 3-4 feet tall. In the
adjacent cattle pasture, a tree is in the process of falling onto the wooden fence resulting in numerous missing and
leaning boards.
Enclosure fencing that is not properly maintained can allow for gaps, unstable structures, or sharp points which can result
in injury, entrapment, or escape of the animals.
Facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain them.
Correct by : March 20, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
End Section

narrative:
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The wolf-dog hybrid, Blackie, is not up-to-date on her rabies vaccination.  Her last rabies vaccination was in May 2019 
and is due every three years (May 2022) as written in the facility's program of veterinary care for dogs.  The animal had a 
physical exam by a veterinarian a month prior to the vaccine due date, however, the facility forgot to vaccinate the dog the 
following month.  The wolf-dog hybrid appeared healthy during the inspection.   
It's important for facilities to follow their program of veterinary care and vaccinate dogs for preventable contagious and 
deadly diseases to ensure their health.   
Each exhibitor with dogs must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that includes vaccinations for diseases 
including rabies, parvovirus and distemper.   
Correct by: March 16, 2023. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The fencing, in the rear of the zebra and cattle pens, has various areas of damage due to fallen trees.  In the zebra 
enclosure, a large tree has fallen onto the wooden fencing which has broken seven of the horizontal boards.  The facility 
has removed the broken boards but the tree remains and the fencing in that area is approximately 3-4 feet tall.  In the

adjacent cattle pasture, a tree is in the process of falling onto the wooden fence resulting in numerous missing and 
leaning boards. 
Enclosure fencing that is not properly maintained can allow for gaps, unstable structures, or sharp points which can result 
in injury, entrapment, or escape of the animals. 
Facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain them. 
Correct by : March 20, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
End Section
